instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message:
hi. i have second problem i dont really understand how to find out whats pulling down voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> when i have 3.3v on  enable pin 47 <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and  pin  46 vcc is 5.01v
TONB pin 1 181 k ohm,  TONA pin 48 181.3 k ohm 



so my voltage on <SIGNAL>IPPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>   is    0.79v

how do i find whats the problem how to find it. Is not water damaged at all

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: What is the history? Liquid, drop, or out of nowhere? Do you get a light on a USB mouse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: no water on it at all and mouse lights is off

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime no display
threads.message: This could literally be anything and isn't going to be easy if even possible to solve Bad PCH, cracked ball under PCH, cracked trace/via somewhere, bad CPU, bad solder ball under CPU. Even if the RAM were bad/had cracked solder ball you should get a light on the mouse. I would look under a microscope to see if anything had fallen off of it or received physical damage but in terms of what to measure/look for I have nothing.
